lines.text: Enter Chamberlain and SANDS

lines.speaker: chamberlain
lines.text: Is't possible the spells of France should juggle Men into such strange mysteries?

lines.speaker: sands
lines.text: New customs, Though they be never so ridiculous, Nay, let 'em be unmanly, yet are follow'd.

lines.speaker: chamberlain
lines.text: As far as I see, all the good our English Have got by the late voyage is but merely A fit or two o' the face; but they are shrewd ones; For when they hold 'em, you would swear directly Their very noses had been counsellors To Pepin or Clotharius, they keep state so.

lines.speaker: sands
lines.text: They have all new legs, and lame ones: one would take it, That never saw 'em pace before, the spavin Or springhalt reign'd among 'em.

lines.speaker: chamberlain
lines.text: Death! my lord, Their clothes are after such a pagan cut too, That, sure, they've worn out Christendom. How now! What news, Sir Thomas Lovell?
Enter LOVELL

lines.speaker: lovell
lines.text: Faith, my lord, I hear of none, but the new proclamation That's clapp'd upon the court-gate.

lines.speaker: chamberlain
lines.text: What is't for?

lines.speaker: lovell
lines.text: The reformation of our travell'd gallants, That fill the court with quarrels, talk, and tailors.

lines.speaker: chamberlain
lines.text: I'm glad 'tis there: now I would pray our monsieurs To think an English courtier may be wise, And never see the Louvre.

lines.speaker: lovell
lines.text: They must either, For so run the conditions, leave those remnants Of fool and feather that they got in France, With all their honourable point of ignorance Pertaining thereunto, as fights and fireworks, Abusing better men than they can be, Out of a foreign wisdom, renouncing clean The faith they have in tennis, and tall stockings, Short blister'd breeches, and those types of travel, And understand again like honest men; Or pack to their old playfellows: there, I take it, They may, 'cum privilegio,' wear away The lag end of their lewdness and be laugh'd at.

lines.speaker: sands
lines.text: 'Tis time to give 'em physic, their diseases Are grown so catching.

lines.speaker: chamberlain
lines.text: What a loss our ladies Will have of these trim vanities!

lines.speaker: lovell
lines.text: Ay, marry, There will be woe indeed, lords: the sly whoresons Have got a speeding trick to lay down ladies; A French song and a fiddle has no fellow.

lines.speaker: sands
lines.text: The devil fiddle 'em! I am glad they are going, For, sure, there's no converting of 'em: now An honest country lord, as I am, beaten A long time out of play, may bring his plainsong And have an hour of hearing; and, by'r lady, Held current music too.

lines.speaker: chamberlain
lines.text: Well said, Lord Sands; Your colt's tooth is not cast yet.

lines.speaker: sands
lines.text: No, my lord; Nor shall not, while I have a stump.

lines.speaker: chamberlain
lines.text: Sir Thomas, Whither were you a-going?

lines.speaker: lovell
lines.text: To the cardinal's: Your lordship is a guest too.

lines.speaker: chamberlain
lines.text: O, 'tis true: This night he makes a supper, and a great one, To many lords and ladies; there will be The beauty of this kingdom, I'll assure you.

lines.speaker: lovell
lines.text: That churchman bears a bounteous mind indeed, A hand as fruitful as the land that feeds us; His dews fall every where.

lines.speaker: chamberlain
lines.text: No doubt he's noble; He had a black mouth that said other of him.

lines.speaker: sands
lines.text: He may, my lord; has wherewithal: in him Sparing would show a worse sin than ill doctrine: Men of his way should be most liberal; They are set here for examples.

lines.speaker: chamberlain
lines.text: True, they are so: But few now give so great ones. My barge stays; Your lordship shall along. Come, good Sir Thomas, We shall be late else; which I would not be, For I was spoke to, with Sir Henry Guildford This night to be comptrollers.

lines.speaker: sands
lines.text: I am your lordship's.
Exeunt
